text: Nice!
<@U0ARRNM3R>: should be finished by tonight
<@U177W7XH8>: <@U0HU55QSD> thanks for taking this and running with it :simple_smile: :+1:
<@U177W7XH8>: when do you expect all changes go be incorporated?
Thanks, <@U0HU55QSD>!

I think the main thing that came out of the call that the reward structure should be written to convince people; to pull them over that last barrier; to answer the less ideological question: but how is Offcourse a fit for me? what do I get out of it?

We also attached to the concept of gamification and focussed on how the tags could be a bridge between the two types of documents. We did notice however that levels and points are meaningless by themselves and those we’re heavily present in the current reward document. To stay in the racing game metaphor: you care about faster cars or new tracks/levels and you care about the thing you have to do to get there, win races, or cross checkpoints to get additional time. 

For developers that last part is clear: code features. The tags are a nice hinge there: they can determine value. It became apparent that there are still quite a bit of ambiguities in the tags that should be cleared up. For instance the autonomy tag is almost a paradox: high autonomy towards people makes the developer more valuable to us. But a highly autonomous feature, in the isolated sense, is not necessarily more valuable. We remained in a struggle with the rewards though, they are hard to clarify/legitimize, although we did spread out the levels of social inclusion more equally.

As for actionables: Sander has some leads on how to improve the document and make it more outwards facing. For me there there are the ambiguities, but my main course of action for the docs will be determined Friday as we structure the entire documentation.
To make it a bit more clear I wrote up a bit of stuff from the call yesterday out of the back of my head just now:
<@U0ARRNM3R>: i'm implementing them in the new reward struture document
Have you decided on next actions?

<@U0ARRNM3R> Sander and I talked yesterday evening about it; but we focussed on the places the two are/could be connected, not so much the internal structure of the documents, although that did pass by a bit.

<@U0HU55QSD>: <@U177W7XH8> I'm working on the notes, which I will post in <#C1ZHZTQAK> shortly. Did you make an appointment yet to go over the structure of the reward document and the issues document? I won't join the appointment, but would like to receive notes of what you discussed, if that's ok?
<http://coderetreat.org/m/blogpost?id=6456126%3ABlogPost%3A53835>
Thanks, <@U0HU55QSD> !

The summer planning is ready! <http://cs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XTlxpOvkjB7I4i-TwXFQ0x8glz75zNaIXDmmcfj1k10/edit|cs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XTlxpOvkjB7I4i-TwXFQ0x8glz75zNaIXDmmcfj1k10/edit>
<!channel>: ^^

Hi everyone, 

We’re meeting tomorrow at 11.00 at ECE. Looking forward to spending a day thinking and tinkering together! 

As for the program: in the morning, we will focus on the feature that we believe is still missing from the platform. As we discussed during the call last week, everybody will think of what can we offer our ideal user *right now* that will make him or her return. 

Please make sure to bring your sketches, wireframes or whatever you prepared (or prepare them tonight ;-)). Keep in mind: 

- think short term (NOW vs. in three months)
- be concrete (your sketches or wireframes should cover this)
- keep our chosen persona in mind (<https://offcourse.slack.com/archives/user-research/p1467729396000002>)

In the afternoon, we will focus on creating user journeys for browsing and curating and we will finish with our weekly call, so Amar can join us for a bit. We will finish the program at 17.00 to have a drink. 

See you all tomorrow! 

Charlotte
